content.text: Thread the string over the pulley and suspend the mass hanger from the end loop of the string, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Measure and record the height \(H\) of the nail above the bench
Record the mass \(m\) that is suspended from the string
m =
Adjust the height of the pulley until the string is parallel to the bench. Measure and record the height \(h\) of the string above the bench
Calculate the value of \((H - h)\)
By adding masses to the hanger, change the total suspended mass \(m\). Repeat **(c)** and **(d)** until you have six sets of values for \(m\) and \(h\)
In your table of results include columns for the values of \(m^2\) and \(\frac{1}{(H-h)^2}\)
R
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{(H - h)^2}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(m^2\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

In this experiment, you will investigate how the equilibrium position of a pivoted wooden strip changes when a horizontal force is applied
Position a metre rule on the two supports as shown in Fig. 2.1, with the supports \(15.0 \text{cm}\) from each end of the rule
Determine the distance \(y\) between the two supports
Measure the height \(h\) of the bottom edge of the mid-point of the rule above the bench
Position the two \(500 \text{g}\) masses on top of the rule, with a mass \(5.0 \text{cm}\) from each end of the rule, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Determine the distance \(x\) of a mass from its nearest support
Measure the height \(h_{1}\) of the bottom edge of the mid-point of the rule above the bench
Calculate the deflection \(d\) of the mid-point of the rule, where \(d = h_1 - h\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\)
percentage uncertainty = .........
Remove the two \(500 \text{g}\) masses and reposition the two supports \(25.0 \text{cm}\) from each end of the rule
Repeat (a)(ii) and (a)(iii)
y =
h =
Position the two \(500 \text{g}\) masses on top of the rule, with a mass \(15.0 \text{cm}\) from each end of the rule
Repeat (b)(ii), (b)(iii) and (c)(i)
x =
d =

where \(k\) is a constant
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)

Explain whether your results support the suggested relationship
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
Please turn over for Question 2
You may not need to use all of the materials provided
In this experiment you will investigate the deflection of a metre rule when two loads are placed on it
